comments.commentBody: And where do you think such public pressure would come from? Things are as they are exactly because this is what the public wants.

Errol, your second sentence is not "obvious" to me.  Please lay out the specifics.  As to what the Saudis are willing to do, if you can get them to make donations of any size to useful causes from gun control to Emily's List, more power to you.

I agree with earlier comments that managing pain and fear at the end of life should be enough for doctors to do. I am hoping there will be discussions of our fear of death. Those will balance out the intense push for assisted suicide at the end of one's life.

I'm here. Nobody felt like cooking so we went out for dinner. Reasonable paella. Not as good as mine, but a lot less work. And a nice Albariño. We're happy.

Very erudite eyebrows on that guy.

"How do you even deal with such people?"

They're a waste of time. There is no dealing with them. The only thing to do is present the data and arguments and move on, making clear you won't be expending any energy on faith-based ignoramuses. Effort should be expended only on those who are open to evidence and reason.

"How do you even deal with such people?"
Well, you can lock them in mental institutions for being delusional, hallucinating, and paranoid. That's the nice way; heck you might cure them.

You can simply ridicule them in public and make sure nobody ever listens to them.

If they actually get into power and refuse to leave peacefully, you usually end up having to fight a war to overthrow them, the way we fought the Civil War to get rid of the insane slaveowner aristocracy. Those guys were completely nuts, too; they actually believed that slaves liked to be enslaved.

We won that Civil War and we would win the next one -- it turns out being delusional is a good way to lose a war -- but it's best to avoid it by keeping these lunatics well away from any positions of power whatsoever.

I am 71 years old, and probably the fifth or fourth most liberal member of my high school graduating class, even though I was barely a dime left of center. I was even a moderate Republican in my youthful years. But I also grew up in "southern southern California"; in other words San Diego County. My class is top heavy with people who cannot stand that Facebook even exists, people whose parents were quite active in the John Birch Society and who floated a lot of rumors that the local Santa Margarita Mountains full full of invading Chinese troops, when in truth Camp Pendleton was training marine recruits to go on attack against the Red Team; in other words, a war game. When Obama won in 2008, I got a steady stream of birther emails. Our class eventually agreed to stay away from religion and politics, but quickly it morphed into 100% evangelism and right-wing hysteria, and 0% opposition. Yes, I have been forced to deal with such people, and if I take care of my health, I might prevail over them, by outliving them.

It can be very difficult to argue history with conservatives. They've apparently got a whole set of history books totally different than AP History tests would cover (perhaps that's why some Republican run states are in the process of banning their students from taking the AP History tests).

Recently, for example, I was informed by not one but TWO conservatives that the Great Depression began in 1932, immediately following the election of FDR, and was caused by business fear of his socialist policies! I attempted to point to a multitude of records detailing the Great Depression beginning in 1929, but they refused to even consider any evidence. When I asked why they wouldn't even look they told me that it wasn't worth wasting their time on, because Obama and the liberals had doctored all the evidence!

How do you even deal with such people?

Agree with the other comments that it's okay, but not great. Okay because the flavor is good, probably because of the onion puree. I did like the addition of the cracked open green cardamom pods. The gravy kept cooking down so I had to add water many times. Maybe that affected the overall flavor. We like many Indian dishes, but this one will not be used again.

Given that Lee is regarded as a hero throughout the South and, to a distressing degree, outside the South, I wonder if we would be better off if he had been tried. Surely Lee was guilty of treason, having taken up arms against the United States.

Lee was a despicable traitor who preferred to serve slave-owning secessionists than to honor his oath to the union, a terrible man whose capabilities as a general in no way diminished the horrible law and society for which he fought desperately and at catastrophic cost. The notion that he was in any way noble, and that he and Grant were in any way equal, is immoral.

politicsbyeccehomo.wordpress.com

But, don't you know-- according to the current crop of candidates for the Republican nomination -- this is all in the past, no one thinks about it anymore.  And Cheney will tell you it was worth all the pain and suffering the veterans went through -- he didn't feel a thing.
Better yet, all relatives of those voting for war who are of suitable age will be in the Van of the battle.
you just stay inside this country and the military will keep you safe and sound so you can continue to prattle.

PS: Why were these "about two dozen" barrels not "discovered" and "declared to be 'Weapons of Mass Deception (or Destruction)"?

Their contents seem toxic enough. Even if dispersed from a little crop-duster, sounds like they'd cause beaucoup "destruction".

Even if they were just rocket-fuel-tanks for those "Use- for-uranium-enrichment-purposes-only centrifuge tubes".

Did the weapons inspectors miss them?

Or did the CheneyRice administration know about the barrels and suppress the information, because they didn't want the smoking WMDs to come in the form of a truckload of pipes, but in a cloud of mushrooms?
Were they perhaps worried that they'd be accused of merely piping 'shrooms in the company of pipe-fitters or plumbers? So odd.

And then there's the DVA--"Old Stonewall," we could call it. They've done OK by me, but I wasn't wounded. As for those that were wounded, there's far to go.

This suggests that for any war Congress lets the president initiate, Congress must first appropriate and set aside the cost of "after-care-'til-death" for each soldier that serves, plus funeral, burial/cremation & headstone expenses.

And it's not like these "solons" don't have a clue as to the costs of war. A lot of 'em are grey enough to remember WW I. WW II. Korea. Vietnam. Iraq I. Afghanistan. Iraq II. Afghanistan II. Pakistan I. Syria I. Libya I (and eventually, every state that has oil-but-not-nukes—this is the US School Yard Bully Foreign Policy at work.)

It is cruel buy easy choice for the Colombians.
Cocaine kills US citizens, spraying kills Colombians.
The US should deal with its problems here in the US not in other countries.
Ditto Mexican drugs.

Your 'guarantee' is worthless and your conclusion about cocaine deaths inaccurate. While some herbicides might not kill people directly or immediately, virtually all of them have a negative impact on a delicately balanced ecosystem. We humans have a nasty habit of inventing artificial chemicals, applying them willy nilly to Earth and all its plants and critters ... and discovering thereafter the unintended effects and consequences of our stupidity. And by the way, cocaine kills people almost exclusively because it's illegal, not because of overdoses.

Ah, but why should the government of Columbia prioritize American's health above the health of their own citizens.

Of course, there is always the possibility of sending the armed forces to liberate the Columbians. The Carter doctrine does state that the uS will use nukes to keep the oil flowing, so we could possibly use that as justification of an invasion of Columbia.
I'm not saying that spraying is the right solution to the coca problem, but this is a ridiculous reason to stop doing it.  I can guarantee you that cocaine kills more people than Roundup does.

I went to a state A&T back in the 70s.  In ag classes we learned about a new herbicide "Round-Up"  after a two day class you could get certification to handle the stuff.  Imagine my surprise when I walked into a hardware store decades later and saw it on the shelves for anyone to buy.

The United States, Monsanto, Round-up, Dyncorp -- Columbia made the right decision and shouldn't look back. Round-up is NOT safe. The EPA is a pawn. More countries like Columbia need and will get on board. Well done, to whomever made this happen.

I agree with your final point, but consider a couple things in your reasoning:  Monsanto lost the patent on Roundup several years ago, so tons of companies produce generic glyphosate.  And the amount being sprayed here is far less than what gets sprayed routinely on our food crops systematically--so there really isn't financial incentive for Monsanto or a general Corporate Conspiracy here.  And do you really think they can just send in legions of unarmed workers to pull up the plants?  They would be shot.  There is a reason they fly above the crops with planes...
But hey, Monsanto says Roundup is safe!

1. spray crops.
2. drive supply of crops down without decreasing demand.
3. increase value of surviving crops and therefore price of processed end-product
4. increase price, increase profit, therefore increase incentive.

I love respect the faceless, inhuman nature of free markets, maybe our the American officials involved in this program should respect it as well.

I wish I could "recommend" your comment ten times over! Legalize and regulate the drugs. That is the only way to go. It won't end drug addition (sorry), but it will end the guns, violence, murder, and other crime that accompany illegal drugs.

I'm somewhat open to this.  I'm willing to at least listen and learn more.  My sense is that you are right.  Grow even MORE and the supply will exceed the demand.  The problem I have with it, is that people like me who never use coca based products may start using it recreationally, so the educational part of your statement has to really be enforced.  Perhaps regulate the dosage/strength so it's so annoying and expensive to get high that it's not worth it.
Better yet, ignore it and spend your money on something more appropriate.

Legalize it, tell the truth about health impacts, tax it, fund treatment for those who are compulsive users and want treatment, and the entire problem will go away. No more money wasted on spraying, prisons, police and courts.
Carpet bombs no, but agriculture use across the country is much more widespread than that.

You do realize that the chemical being sprayed in Colombia is the same that you use in your yard, right?

It's Round Up, the same stuff that you spray near your children just so you can have a nice yard.

Well we do carpet bomb ourselves with poison. It is called monsanto and industrial agriculture. We invent poisons, the intended targets evolve to be immune to such poisons so Big Agribusiness must make more lethal poisons. The Boards and CEO's of the bg chemical companies do not live anywhere near where these poisons are used.
I think this is a positive development. But just think of how much glyphosate is dumped on lands in the US. A lot!

Judging from the online comments, it seems the article neglected to give space to the role of corporations that were part of this aerial spraying process. I would assume that this has received a lot of attention in Colombia. To what degree was this aerial spraying policy a product of US corporate interests vs. 'war on drugs' policy?

Let's just make the drugs legal.

The solution is as simple as that

Others here point out the absurdity of your comparison of same-sex marriage to polygamy and incest.  But if you examine your feelings, your motivation for such an argument, it is not because you are following a rigorous logic, but rather because you are trying to use fear to promote hatred.  You hate LGBT people.  And because you hate them, you fear them, and want others to do the same.  The same thing is true of your raising the specter of a coming backlash by comparing same-sex marriage to legal abortion.  You are just trying to scare people.
The spraying was being done with the *cooperation* of the Colombian government, so you should start there if you want to criticize someone.

OK, I am being hyperbolic, but I still don't like how the US imposes it's will on these countries and I don't think Americans would stand for aerial spraying of National Parks in California with known drug harvesting.

@T Montoya: "... I still don't like how the US imposes it's will on these countries ..."

OK, then you might find this book about the so-called war on drugs informative: "Killing Pablo" by Mark Bowden.
How can Americans destroy someone else's neighborhood because we can't manage the drug use of our own people? If some other country did this to us we would start bombing before the weekend.

Dear Pushkin,

While I agree with your points, I would like to ask you to please remember the proper spelling of the country is Colombia not Columbia. I'm sure it was a casual mistake however, it is something we Colombians associate with the many misrepresentations our country faces and have tried decades to actively combat. Please see here: http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303603904579495481490796654

Respectfully,
Carolina

Good decision by the government of Columbia. Spraying of anything on a wide area is rife with problems. Better to be safe now than sorry later. Let us not forget "agent orange", the defoliant.
The reason for growing cocoa plants is driven by demand from users-and the US has the most users of any country. It would appear that a more cost effective and safer method would be interdiction where processing takes place-where large quantities of raw cocaine are being processed. The ultimate target must be to reduce the number of users in the US-by some intervention into the cultural/economic drivers which make cocaine attractive to so many. It is time for America to look inward to solve this and other problems-not to expect producer countries to do it. The example of Afghanistan stands in bold relief-the world's largest producer of heroin-and production goes ahead every year without much noise from America.

Progressives are playing in the wrong game. Progressives play table tennis politics while Republicans play their own version of muddy, leather ball rugby politics. Progressives view themselves as the truth seekers and natural defenders against the revisionists, little more. Memo to Dem: Rear guard actions are so yesterday. Republicans on the other hand know winners have to score - and they do.

Progressives have to change their game. They must take to the pitch fired up as loud, in your face, shameless champions of those in middle class, those recently removed from the middle class and those seeking to enter the middle class. They must seize the narrative, endlessly and shamelessly everywhere. They must fight for and be identified with a cause - any progressive cause.

No wonder Senator Warren stands out against the shadow shrouded progressive agenda. What a pleasant and exhilarating contrast she is when compared to the ever polite cloying centrists in her party.
Old Round Up was 2-4D, as is true Glyphosate but it is hard to find the good, straight stuff as a retail consumer anymore.

Glyphosate is an entirely different chemical than 24D or 245T.  t is a systemic herbicide unlike the other two and is in every bite of food you eat today unless you eat organic.  There are a billion pounds used worldwide every year.  In addition to the effects mentioned it disrupts gut bacteria and is suspected of contributing to autism and digestive disorders like celiac disease.  Bad stuff.

Tractor Supply, AgriSupply, and any rural seed and feed operation have plenty of the stuff in stock. And honestly, I'd like a straight answer about this stuff, not one from the EPA, or Monsanto, or WHO. I don't consider any of them to be credible sources; unfortunately all of them have enormous influence over what studies are conducted and what methodologies are employed in reaching their contradictory positions.

The same US government told us Agent Orange was benign.
There is a museum in Ha Noi with deformed fetuses, like with a foot growing out of the head, from that wonder poison.
It can only be coincidence that glyphosate, or Round Up is 2-4 and
Agent Orange is 2-4-5

The U.S. could help the Columbian government with denial about health effects, given its experience in denying about Agent Orange and denying about exposure to a number of toxins in the Forever War in Iraq.
Just legalize drugs. That is the only way to end the violence associated with illegal drugs.

@Boston Benny: "... backed by the DEA."

Not just the DEA. The US military has been involved too. See "Killing Pablo" by Mark Bowden.
Who manufactures the glyphosate that is sprayed? Well, there you go then.

America's War on drugs has been a dismal and expensive failure. In many regards, America's figurative war has created a literal war Colombia. I haven't seen any recent numbers, but for many years Colombia was tops on the U.N's unexplained missing peoples list. The demand for cocaine in America and the War on Drugs caused a multi-front war in Colombia between drug cartels, Farc, the Colombian army and police and right-wing paramilitaries backed by the DEA.
Its time to seriously rethink the "War" and come up more effective ways to deal with drugs in this country. Its clear that no amount of war will stop drugs from entering America or stop people from using them

Perhaps the WHO could do a study and spray Tennessee with harmless glyphosate for 10 years and study the effects. Its easy to say not a problem when spraying Colombians with roundup but maybe not so comfortable if we try the poison ourselves.
Wait, did you just assert that the World Health Organization has been bought by drug lords?  But no mention of political influence exerted upon our own EPA?  That is some funny stuff.

It now makes sense why WHO created a new category of hazard, "probably causes cancer", that does not require any scientific evidence, to discourage the use of glyphosate.  They have been bought by the drug lords.
